ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Policies and scientific studies surrounding environmental issues in the Caribbean
Understanding about the environmental issues that affect the Carribbean most. Critical evaluation of policy measures to address these issues.

I gained insight into both the scientific and management aspects of coastal development and its ecological impacts in the Caribbean. We covered a wide variety of topics from coral reef biology to co-management, covering various papers on each subject.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Comments and suggestions on final paper were sent out 2 days before presentation on paper was due.

Strengths: student presentations were interesting and gave you an opportunity to engage in depth with a topic. I also enjoyed the other students' presentations and seeing how they apply their background and perspectives to the issue they are presenting about. Weaknesses: a bit disorganized with the syllabus, spent too much time on sedimentation, the readings were dense academic articles that were difficult to truly understand if you don't have a science background

Strengths: knowledgeable kind professors, interesting subject matter and research
Weaknesses: lectures droned on at times, class and activities could be monotonous

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if interested in downing down environmental science or marine science career
Yes, this is one of the few env policy classes offered at the undergraduate level. Caribbean issues can be easily applied to other coastal areas if that is your interest.

Yes! I learned a lot about the ecological, political, and socioeconomic aspects of coastal development in the Caribbean and came away with a rich understanding of the vast subject at hand. My one caveat is that the workload is pretty high, due to students each leading a lecture and completing a final original research project over the course of the semester on top of weekly readings. If you're up to it, it's totally worth it for the learning experience you come away with!
